article.title: Random Walk Sampling for Big Data over Networks

multiple_choice_question.text: Which statement best describes the "smoothness hypothesis" in graph signal processing?
choices: Graph signals always resemble smooth, continuous functions.
The underlying graph structure is regular and free of sharp changes.
Signal values of nodes within the same cluster tend to be similar.
The recovery of a graph signal should prioritize minimizing sharp transitions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary goal of the "random walk sampling" strategy described in the article?
choices: To explore all possible paths through a graph.
To analyze the connectivity patterns of random graphs.
To select a subset of nodes that effectively represent the entire graph signal.
To optimize the speed of graph traversal algorithms.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to the article, why is it beneficial to sample more densely in clusters with a larger cut-size?
choices: Larger clusters contain more information by definition.
Nodes in larger clusters are more likely to be influential.
Clusters with larger cut-sizes have more connections to other clusters, making them more informative about the overall graph signal.
The random walk algorithm naturally prioritizes larger clusters.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the Sparse Label Propagation (SLP) algorithm in the context of this article?
choices: To efficiently label nodes in a graph based on their attributes.
To recover the entire graph signal from a limited set of observed samples.
To identify the most representative nodes within each cluster.
To visualize the structure of large, complex graphs.
